CHEERS FROM THE PIT ACCOMPANY A CODA: THE MET'S CONCERTMASTER IS
RETIRING 

   By ANTHONY TOMMASINI   
 c.2000 N.Y. Times News Service    

   NEW YORK _ When Raymond Gniewek was appointed concertmaster of
the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra in 1957, he was a 25-year-old
graduate of the Eastman School of Music with scant experience in
vocal music, let alone opera. Though he was a brilliantly talented
violinist, he immediately became the youngest member of the
orchestra, its first American-born concertmaster, and he was
expected to assume a leadership role among musicians far more
knowledgeable than he about the European opera heritage.

   Things obviously turned out well. After 43 years as
concertmaster _ a position little understood even by regular
concertgoers _ Gniewek, 68, is retiring. During his tenure he has
performed in 115 different operas under a roster of conductors
ranging from some now-forgotten beat-keepers to giants like Dmitri
Mitropoulos, Karl Boehm, Herbert von Karajan, Leonard Bernstein
and, of course, James Levine. An opera neophyte when he arrived, he
leaves with an incomparable understanding of operatic style and
practice. In 1977 he even married a singer, the soprano Judith
Blegen.

   His final performances come this weekend with two concerts by
the Met Orchestra conducted by Levine: Friday night at the New
Jersey Performing Arts Center in Newark, and on Sunday afternoon at
Carnegie Hall, an all-Bartok program offering the one-act opera
``Bluebeard's Castle'' and the Concerto for Orchestra. Count on
Levine, who was a precocious 13-year-old piano student in
Cincinnati when Gniewek got the Met job, to acknowledge him warmly
at the end of the concert.

   During an interview the other day in his office, Levine grew
emotional trying to explain how important Gniewek has been to the
artistic growth of the orchestra. They share a musical heritage,
since two of Levine's teachers, the conductors Jean Morel and
Fausto Cleva, were important figures at the Met during Gniewek's
early years. ``The single luckiest thing to happen to me since I
have been at the Met,'' Levine said, ``is that Ray Gniewek was the
concertmaster.''

   Many operagoers will have to accept Levine's tribute on faith,
since there are such misconceptions about the role. What exactly
does a concertmaster do?

   ``It's hard to put into words,'' the silver-haired, fit and
affable Gniewek said during a recent interview at the Met. In the
18th century, ``before conductors were even around,'' he said,
``the concertmaster essentially led the orchestra, for the simple
reason that the violin was the highest voice in any ensemble.''

   He continued: ``As music became more complicated, and more
instruments were involved, communication between the musicians
didn't work very well. So a director, a conductor, was put there,
to keep things in order.''

   This outmoded historic conception of the concertmaster as a sort
of second in command, ready to assume the podium if the conductor
should be unable to continue, has persisted in the public
imagination, Gniewek said. But all major orchestras have a number
of assistant conductors on staff. The Met has a whole roster of
them.

   Like most modern concertmasters, Gniewek has a different set of
responsibilities. The public notices his work most when he plays
solos in an opera. These can range in length and difficulty from
the short, bittersweet melody that comforts Strauss' introspective
Marschallin at the end of Act I in ``Der Rosenkavalier'' to the
miniconcerto that functions as an orchestral interlude in Act III
of Verdi's ``I Lombardi.''

   More important, he acts as a leader of the violin section,
responsible for making sure that all phrasing, bowings and
articulations are being done the same way by everyone. In a house
with the heritage of the Met, such solutions have long been
established and are written into the orchestra parts. But a
conductor is free to change them. In that case the concertmaster
must find a technical solution to the conductor's wishes and
communicate it somehow to the other musicians.

   ``Players tell me all the time, `Don't worry, Ray, we're
watching the tip of your bow,''' Gniewek said. But many things have
to be dealt with in detail, on the spot, in rehearsal:

   ``For example, Jimmy will say, `No, Ray, I want this phrase a
little lighter, a little shorter.' So I'll play it. He'll say: `No,
that's too short. Just a little brushing sound, tat-tat-tat.' I'll
play again. `That's it!' he'll say. So I turn to the violins and
demonstrate. It's my job to make technical translations of the
desired sound. And you have to show, not tell, because the same
words can mean different things to different people.''

   This intuitive way of working has been essential to Levine,
whose goal has been to make the Met orchestra sound ``like a
sensational, huge chamber group.'' This is critical in opera, where
timing should be free and expressive, and where, ideally, the
conductor and orchestra respond to the singers the way a pianist
accompanies a voice recital.

   Sometimes, when a conductor is waiting on a singer's response,
Gniewek said, ``there is a lag between them, between what is
happening onstage and what is happening in the pit.'' If there is
any uncertainty, the orchestra players ``feel a little surer if
they can follow me,'' he said. ``I mean, I make a sound. The
conductor's beat doesn't. So if they jump in when I start to play,
they know they will be safe.''

   nn

    

   Some modern-day concertmasters have also been aspiring
conductors, the most renowned example being Joseph Silverstein, who
resigned as concertmaster of the Boston Symphony Orchestra in 1984
after 22 years to become the conductor of the Utah Symphony
Orchestra. Gniewek ``never had the itch'' to conduct, he said.
``I'd rather play. I have strong feelings about sound, the actual
act of playing of the instrument. It's what I do best.''

   He certainly must have done it impressively to win his post at
such a young age, especially considering that his focus on a
musical career came late. He was born in East Meadow, on Long
Island, to a mother who loved music and sang in a church choir, and
a Polish immigrant father who had played the violin at dances in
Poland but wound up working as a barber in America.

   ``The family joke was that my parents' first son was going to be
a violinist,'' Gniewek said. Coming after two sisters, he was the
first son. He became the violinist. ``I had no choice,'' he said
wryly. ``I never really took to practicing too well. I loved math
and science.''

   He intended to be a physics major and was accepted by the
Massachusetts Institute of Technology. But he was persuaded to
attend the University of Rochester, where, somehow, he said, he
wound up enrolling at the affiliated Eastman School of Music. Erich
Leinsdorf, who had been conducting at the Met since 1938, was the
director of the Rochester Philharmonic Orchestra at the time and
invited Gniewek to be its concertmaster. But it was the conductor
Max Rudolf, then an assistant manager at the Met, who worked with
Gniewek in Rochester and told him of the opening at the Met.

   The concertmaster appointment came at a difficult time in
Gniewek's life. His first marriage, which produced two daughters,
was breaking up. ``I was 20 when we got married,'' he said. ``We
were just too young.''

   The Met musicians might have been expected to be resentful of
this young newcomer. But, Gniewek said, ``I sort of waded my way
through things, wasn't too arrogant, and the musicians were very
supportive.''

   Surely he earned that support through the quality of his
musicianship. Today, after four decades of absorbing operatic
style, his playing has a special vocal quality, Levine said: ``It
shimmers, it's lyrical. You can imagine putting a text to it
immediately.''

   When Gniewek joined the Met, the autocratic Rudolf Bing was in
his seventh year as general manager. However Bing's tenure is
regarded today, he was ``a singer's man,'' Gniewek said. ``To him,
we were just an accompanying orchestra.''

   He remembers Levine's 1971 debut as a turning point. ``When
Jimmy came, it was the end of the season, just another `Tosca' for
us,'' Gniewek recalled. ``But he really lifted us up and carried us
along. Afterward I did something I didn't do much. I found him
backstage and said, `That was the most phenomenal debut since
Herbert von Karajan.'''

   The morale in the orchestra, in that next-to-last year of the
Bing era, was not high. Levine's positivism was just the tonic
needed, Gniewek said. He sometimes chides jaded friends from the
New York Philharmonic who are suspicious of Levine's enthusiasm.

   ``They tell me, `Ah, he's always smiling.'

   ` `What's wrong with that?' I say. `You have to always make
music scowling? Music always has to be done with suffering and
intensity?'''

   There have been times when Gniewek was so exhilarated after a
Met performance _ many nights with Birgit Nilsson and Renata
Tebaldi, he said, and Wagner's ``Ring'' with Levine _ that he would
go home and stay up until 4 a.m. doing things like tiling the
bathroom floor. He would have retired years ago, he said, but he
wanted to be a part of two transforming additions to the
orchestra's musical life introduced by Levine over the last 10
years: the Met Orchestra concert series and the founding of the Met
Chamber Ensemble.

   During his tenure Gniewek has witnessed a turnover of orchestra
personnel; only three players have been there longer than he.
Naturally, he was very involved with the auditions for string
players, though he said he was ``not 100 percent happy'' with the
process. To prevent discrimination, the candidates play from behind
a screen, and the musicians on the audition committee write down
their comments without consultation.

   ``I would like to have a little discussion,'' he said.
``Sometimes you don't completely trust what you are hearing.'' For
example, was a violinist's playing exciting, or a bit aggressive?
Different listeners may feel differently. Also, although he accepts
the reasons for it, he has been frustrated by the use of the
screen.

   ``I like to see a person playing,'' he said. ``Playing an
instrument is a very physical thing.'' If there are problems after
the fact, the contract allows for a two-year probation period
during which a newcomer can be removed.

   Only the concertmaster can be appointed directly by the artistic
director, Levine. The Met orchestra has traditionally had two
principal players of each instrument, but only one concertmaster,
though there are several associates. Levine has been seeking to
change that policy, and over the last season a second
concertmaster, Nick Eanet, 28, whom everyone is excited about, was
finally broken in. Gniewek is now taking part in the audition
process to find another concertmaster to share the work with Eanet.

   Gniewek knows that playing in an opera house orchestra involves
a lot of hard, routine work, day after day. But he always had an
answer for musicians who found themselves feeling uninspired.

   ``I'd tell people: `You are going to be here for four hours
anyway. Do you want to walk out feeling: ``Ugh! What a headache!
That was not so good''? Or do you want to walk out feeling, ``Wow,
that was fantastic'' '? Might as well give it everything.''

   And that explains exactly what a concertmaster does.
